question: Why don't I open the viewport? Watch your eyes. And how are we today?
answer: Terrible.

question: Just terrible? That's better than yesterday at least.
answer: How long have I been on Gateway station?

question: Just a couple of days. Do you feel up to a visitor?
answer: Jones! Come here Jonesy you ugly old moose...you ugly thing. How long was I out there? They won't tell me anything.

question: Jones! Come here Jonesy you ugly old moose...you ugly thing. How long was I out there? They won't tell me anything.
answer: Well, maybe you shouldn't worry about that just yet.

question: How long?
answer: All right. My instinct says you're strong enough to handle this...Fifty-seven years.

question: Fifty-seven...oh, Christ...
answer: You'd drifted right through the core systems. It's blind luck that deep-salvage team caught you when they...are you all right?

question: No.. I've slept enough. We made it, Jones. We made it. Dumbshit.
answer: Sorry...I've been running behind all morning.

question: Have they located my daughter yet?
answer: Well, I was going to wait until after the inquest...

question: Is she...?
answer: Amanda Ripley-McClaren. Married name, I guess. Age

question: Amy.
answer: Cancer. Hmmmm. They still haven't licked that one. Cremated. Interred Parkside Repository, Little Chute, Wisconsin. No children.

question: I promised her I'd be home for her birthday. Her eleventh birthday. I sure missed that one. Well...she has already learned to take my promises with a grain of salt. When it came to flight schedules, anyway. You always think you can make it up to somebody...later, you know. But now I never can. I never can.
answer: The hearing convenes at 0930. You don't want to be late.

question: You read my deposition...it's complete and accurate.
answer: Look, I believe you, but there are going to be some heavyweights in there. You got Feds, you got interstellar commerce commission, you got colonial administration, insurance company guys...

question: I get the picture.
answer: Just tell them what happened. The important thing is to stay cool and unemotional.

question: Do you people have earwax, of what? We have been here three hours. How many different ways do you want me to tell the same story?
answer: Look at it from our perspective. You freely admit to detonating the engines of, and thereby destroying, an M-Class star-freighter. A rather expensive piece of hardware... The shuttle's flight recorder corroborates some elements of your account. That the Nostromo set down on LV-426, an unsurveyed planet, at that time. That repairs were made. That it resumed its course and was subsequently set for self-destruct. By you. For reasons unknown.

question: Look, I told you...
answer: It did not, however, contain any entries concerning the hostile life form you allegedly picked up.

question: Then somebody's gotten to it... doctored the recorder. Who had access to it?
answer: The analysis team which went over your shuttle centimeter by centimeter found no physical evidence of the creature you describe...

question: That's because I blew it out the Goddamn airlock! Like I said. I told you, it wasn't indigenous. There was an alien spacecraft there. A derelict ship. We homed on its beacon... Look, I can see where this is going. But I'm telling you those things exist. Back on that planetoid is an alien ship and on that ship are thousands of eggs. Thousands. Do you understand? I suggest you find it, using the flight recorder's data. Find it and deal with it -- before one of your survey teams comes back with a little surprise...
answer: Thank you, Officer Ripley. That will be...

question: ...because just one of those things managed to kill my entire crew, within twelve hours of hatching...
answer: Thank you, that will be all.

question: It is the finding of this board of inquiry that Warrent Officer Ellen Ripley, NOC-14672. has acted with questionable judgment and is unfit to hold an ICC license as a commercial flight officer. Said license is hereby suspended indefinitely. No criminal charges will be filed at this time and you are released on own recognizance for a six month period of psychometric probation, to include monthly review by an ICC psychiatric tech...
answer: Why won't you check out LV-426?

question: Because I don't have to. The people who live there checked it out years ago and they never reported and 'hostile organism' or alien ship. And by the way, they call it Acheron now.
answer: What are you talking about. What people?

question: Terraformers...planet engineers. It's what we call a shake 'n' bake colony. They set up atmosphere processors to make the air breathable...big job. Takes decades. They've already been there over twenty years. Peacefully.
answer: How many colonists?

question: Sixty, maybe seventy families.
answer: Sweet Jesus.

question: And half mine!
answer: I got too many partners.

question: Daddy, when are we going back to town?
answer: When we get rich, Newt.

question: Hi, Ripley. This is Lieutenant Gorman of the... Ripley we have to talk. They've lost contact with the colony on Acheron.
answer: No. There's no way!

question: Hear me out...
answer: I was reamed, steamed and dry-cleaned by you guys...and now you want me to go back out there? Forget it.

question: What about you? What's your interest in this?
answer: Well, the corporation co-financed that colony with the Colonial Administration, against mineral rights. We're getting into a lot of terraforming...'Building Better Worlds.'

question: Yeah, yeah. I saw the commercial.
answer: I heard you were working in the cargo docks.

question: That's right.
answer: Running loaders, forklifts, that sort of thing?

question: It's all I could get. Anyway, it keeps my mind off of... everything. Days off are worse.
answer: What if I said I could get you reinstated as a flight officer? And that the company has agreed to pick up your contract?

question: If I go.
answer: If you go. It's a second chance, kiddo. And it'll be the best thing in the world for you to face this fear and beat it. You gotta get back on the horse...

question: Spare me, Burke. I've had my psych evaluation this month.
answer: Yes, and I've read it. You wake up every night, sheets soaking, the same nightmare over and over...

question: No! The answer is no. Now please go. I'm sorry. Just go, would you.
answer: Think about it. Yello? Oh, Ripley. Hi...

question: Burke, just tell me one thing. That you're going out there to kill them. Not study. Not bring back. Just burn them out...clean ...forever.
answer: That's the plan. My word on it.

question: Well, it didn't occur to me. It's been policy for years to have a synthetic on board.
answer: I prefer the term 'artificial person' myself. Is there a problem?

question: A synthetic malfunctioned on her last trip out. Some deaths were involved.
answer: I'm shocked. Was it an older model?

question: Cyberdyne Systems 120-A/2.
answer: Well, that explains it. The A/2's were always a bit twitchy. That could never happen now with out behavioral inhibitors. Impossible for me to harm or, by omission of action, allow to be harmed a human being. More cornbread?

question: At ease. I'm sorry we didn't have time to brief before we left Gateway but...
answer: Sir?

question: Yes, Hicks?
answer: Hudson, Sir. He's Hicks.

question: What's the question?
answer: Is this going to be a stand-up fight, Sir, on another bug-hunt?

question: Set down sixty meters this side of the telemetry mast. Immediate dust off on my 'clear,' then stay on station.
answer: Ten seconds, people. Look sharp!

question: First squad up, on line. Hicks, get yours in a cordon. Watch the rear.
answer: Vasquez, take point. Let's move. Sealed. Hudson, run a bypass. First squad, assemble on me at the main lock.

question: I don't know how you managed to stay alive but you're one brave kid, Rebecca.
answer: N-newt.

question: What did you say?
answer: Newt. My n-name's Newt. Nobody calls me Rebecca except my dork brother.

question: Well, Newt it is then. My name's Ripley...and people call me Ripley. Pleased to meet you. And who is this? Does she have a name?
answer: Casey. She's my only friend.

question: What about me?
answer: I don't want you for a friend.

question: Why not?
answer: Because you'll be gone soon, like the others. Like everybody. You'll be dead and you'll leave me alone.

question: Oh, Newt. You mom and dad went away like that, didn't they? They'd be here if they could, honey. I know they would.
answer: They're dead.

question: Newt. Look at me...Newt. I won't leave you. I promise.
answer: You promise?

question: Cross my heart.
answer: And hope to die?

question: Flame thrower! Move!
answer: Movement!

question: Position?
answer: Can't lock up...

question: Talk to me, Hudson.
answer: Uh, seems to be in front and behind.

question: No good. How do we know it'll effect their biochemistry? I say we take off and nuke the entire site from orbit. It's the only way to be sure.
answer: Now hold on a second. I'm not authorizing that action.

question: Why not?
answer: Well, I mean...I know this is an emotional moment, but let's not make snap judgments. Let's move cautiously. First, this physical installation had a substantial dollar value attached to it --

question: They can bill me. I got a tab running. What's second?
answer: This is clearly an important species we're dealing with here. We can't just arbitrarily exterminate them --

question: Look, Burke. We had an agreement.
answer: I know, I know, but we're dealing with changing scenarios here. This thing is major, Ripley. I mean really major. You gotta go with its energy. Since you are the representative of the company who discovered this species your percentage will naturally be some serious, serious money.

question: You son of a bitch.
answer: Don't make me pull rank, Ripley.

question: What rank? I believe Corporal Hicks has authority here.
answer: Corporal Hicks!?

question: Now you just lie here and have a nap. You're exhausted.
answer: I don't want to...I have scary dreams.

question: I'll bet Casey doesn't have bad dreams. Nothing bad in here. Maybe you could just try to be like her.
answer: Ripley...she doesn't have bad dreams because she's just a piece of plastic.

question: Oh. Sorry, Newt.
answer: My mommy always said there were no monsters. No real ones. But there are.

question: Yes, there are, aren't there.
answer: Why do they tell little kids that?

question: Well, some kids can't handle it like you can.
answer: Did one of those things grow inside her?

question: I don't know, Newt. That's the truth.
answer: Isn't that how babies come? I mean people babies...they grow inside you?

question: No, it's different, honey.
answer: Did you ever have a baby?

question: Yes. A little girl.
answer: Where is she?

question: Gone.
answer: You mean dead. Ripley, I was just thinking... Maybe I could do you a favor and fill in for her. Just for a while. You can try it and if you don't like it, it's okay. I'll understand. No big deal. Whattya think?

question: I think it's not the worst idea I've heard all day. Let's talk about it later.
answer: Don't go! Please.

question: I'll be right in the other room, Newt. And look...I can see you on that camera right up there. Here. Take is for luck. Now go to sleep...and don't dream. How is he?
answer: I've isolated a neuro-muscular toxin responsible for the paralysis. It seems to be metabolizing. He should wake up soon.

question: Now let me get this straight. The aliens paralyzed the colonists, carried them over there, cocooned them to be hosts for more of those... Which would mean lots of those parasites, right? One for each person...over a hundred at least.
answer: Yes. That follows.

question: But these things come from eggs...so where are all the eggs coming from.
answer: That is the question of the hour. We could assume a parallel to certain insect forms who have hivelike organization. An ant of termite colony, for example, is ruled by a single female, a queen, which is the source of new eggs.

question: You're saying one of those things lays all the eggs?
answer: Well, the queen is always physically larger then the others. A termite queen's abdomen is so bloated with eggs that it can't move at all. It is fed and tended by drone workers, defended by the warriors. She is the center of their lives, quite literally the mother of their society.

question: Could it be intelligent?
answer: Hard to say. It may have been blind instinct...attraction to the heat of whatever...but she did choose to incubate her eggs in the one spot where we couldn't destroy her without destroying ourselves. That's if she exists, of course.

question: I want those specimens destroyed as soon as you're done with them. You understand?
answer: Mr. Burke have instructions that they were to be kept alive in stasis for return to the company labs. He was very specific.

question: Burke!
answer: Those specimens are worth millions to the bio-weapons division. Now, if you're smart we can both come out of this heroes. Set up for life.

question: You just try getting a dangerous organism past ICC quarantine. Section 22350 of the Commerce Code.
answer: You've been doing your homework. Look, they can't impound it if they don't know about it.

question: But they will know about it, Burke. From me. Just like they'll know how you were responsible for the deaths of one hundred and fifty-seven colonists here --
answer: Now, wait a second --

question: You sent them to that ship. I just checked the colony log... directive dates six-twelve-seventy-nine. Signed Burke, Carter J. You sent them out there and you didn't even warn them, Burke. Why didn't you warn them?
answer: Look, maybe the thing didn't even exist, right? And if I'd made it a major security situation, the Administration would've stepped in. Then no exclusive rights, nothing. It was a bad call, that's all.

question: Bad call? These people are fucking dead, Burke! Well, they're going to nail your hide to the shed... and I'll be there when they do.
answer: I expected more of you, Ripley. I thought you would be smarter than this.

question: We need the other drop-ship. The on one the Sulaco. We have to bring it down on remote, somehow.
answer: How? The transmitter was on the APC. It's wasted.

question: I don't care how! Think of a way. Think of something.
answer: Think of what? We're fucked.

question: They're in the approach corridor.
answer: On my way.

question: Twenty meters and closing. Fifteen. C and D guns down about fifty percent.
answer: Now many?

question: Can't tell. Lots. D gun's down to twenty. Ten. It's out.
answer: They retreated. The guns stopped them.

question: Yeah. But look... Newt time then can walk right up and knock.
answer: But they don't know that. They're probably looking for other ways to get in. That'll take them awhile.

question: I want you two walking the perimeter. I know we're all in strung out shape but stay frosty and alert. We've got to stop any entries before they get out of hand. How long since you slept? Twenty-four hours?
answer: They'll get us.

question: Maybe. Maybe not.
answer: Hicks, I'm not going to wind up like those others. You'll take care of it won't you, it if comes to that?

question: If it comes to that, I'll do us both. Let's see that it doesn't Here, I'd like to introduce you to a close personal friend of mine. M-41A 10mm pulse-rifle, over and under with a 30mm pump-action grenade launcher.
answer: What do I do?

question: Just pull it in real right. It will kick some. When the counter here heads zero, hit this... Just let it drop right out. Get the other one in quick. Just slap it in hard, it likes abuse. Now, pull the bolt. You're ready again.
answer: What's this?

question: Well, that's the grenade launcher ...you probably don't want to mess with that.
answer: Look, you started this. Now show me everything. I can handle myself.

question: Yeah. I've noticed.
answer: How do you feel?

question: Get back here, both of you. Fall back to Operations.
answer: This signal's weird...must be some interference or something. There's movement all over the place...

question: Just get back here!
answer: Movement! Signal's clean. Range twenty meters.

question: Seal the door.
answer: Seventeen meters.

question: Fifteen meters.
answer: I don't know, an acid hole in a duct. Something under the floors, not on the plans. I don't know!

question: Twelve meters. Man, this is a big fucking signal. Ten meters.
answer: They're right on us. Vasquez, how you doing?

question: Nine meters. Eight.
answer: Can't be. That's inside the room!

question: Come on! This way.
answer: Stay behind me.

question: Come on. Crawl faster.
answer: DO you know how to get to the landing field from here?

question: This way. Come on, we're almost there!
answer: Newt, wait!

question: Here! Go up. Just up there -- Riiiiipppleee --
answer: Newt!

question: Mommy...where are you? Moooommeeee...
answer: Hicks, get down here. I need that locator. Newt! Star wherever you are!

question: Climb down, honey. We have to cut through this grate. Newt! Newt! No! Noooo!
answer: She's gone! Let's go!

question: No! No! She's alive! We have to --
answer: All right! She's alive. I believe it. But we gotta get moving! Now!

question: Come on, you can make it. Almost there. HOW MUCH TIME?
answer: PLENTY! TWENTY-SIX MINUTES!

question: WE'RE NOT LEAVING!
answer: Ripley...

question: She's alive. They brought her here and you know it.
answer: In seventeen minutes this place will be a cloud of vapor the size of Nebraska.

question: Hicks, don't let him leave.
answer: We ain't going anywhere.

question: See you, Hicks.
answer: Dwayne. It's Dwayne.

question: Ellen.
answer: Don't be long, Ellen.

question: Newt, I want you to hang on, now. Hang on tight. BISHOP! BISHOP! Close your eyes, baby. Punch it, Bishop! It's okay, baby. We made it. It's over.
answer: I gave him a shot, for the pain. We'll need to get a stretcher to cart him up to medical. I'm sorry if I gave you a scare but that platform was just becoming too unstable... I had to circle and hope things didn't get too rough to take you off.

question: You did okay, Bishop.
answer: Well, thanks, I --

question: Go! Here! Get away from her, you bitch! Come on!
answer: Not bad for a human.
